children.value: Use Taylor’s theorem to derive finite difference approximations for derivatives and analyze their accuracy. Understanding the interplay between approximation error and round-off error is fundamental to scientific computing.

children.html: f(x)=Pk(x)⏟k-th Taylor polynomial+Rk(x)⏟Remainder or error term=∑i=0kf(i)(x0)i!(x−x0)i+f(k+1)(ξ)(k+1)!(x−x0)k+1,\begin{split} f(x) &= \underbrace{P_k(x)}_{\text{$k$-th Taylor polynomial}} + \underbrace{R_k(x)}_{\text{Remainder or error term}} \\ &= \sum_{i=0}^{k} \frac{f^{(i)}(x_0)}{i!} (x - x_0)^i + \frac{f^{(k+1)}(\xi)}{(k+1)!}(x - x_0)^{k+1}, \end{split}f(x)​=k-th Taylor polynomialPk​(x)​​+Remainder or error termRk​(x)​​=i=0∑k​i!f(i)(x0​)​(x−x0​)i+(k+1)!f(k+1)(ξ)​(x−x0​)k+1,​

children.value: To estimate the error, we compute the remainder:

children.html: Rn(x)=f(n+1)(ξ)(n+1)!xn+1R_n(x) = \frac{f^{(n+1)}(\xi)}{(n+1)!}x^{n+1}Rn​(x)=(n+1)!f(n+1)(ξ)​xn+1
ξ∈[0,1]\xi \in [0, 1]ξ∈[0,1]
exe^xex
sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣Rn(x)∣≤ex(n+1)!≤3(n+1)!.\sup_{x \in [0, 1]}|R_n(x)| \leq \frac{e^x}{(n+1)!} \leq \frac{3}{(n+1)!}.x∈[0,1]sup​∣Rn​(x)∣≤(n+1)!ex​≤(n+1)!3​.
sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣Rn(x)∣≤10−3  ⟹  3(n+1)!≤10−3.\sup_{x \in [0, 1]}|R_n(x)| \leq 10^{-3} \quad\implies\quad \frac{3}{(n+1)!} \leq 10^{-3}.x∈[0,1]sup​∣Rn​(x)∣≤10−3⟹(n+1)!3​≤10−3.

children.alt: The first four Taylor polynomials P_1, P_2, P_3, P_4 of f(x) = e^x centered at x_0 = 0. The approximations converge to the true function (dashed black) as the degree increases.

children.html: P1,P2,P3,P4P_1, P_2, P_3, P_4P1​,P2​,P3​,P4​

children.value: . The approximations converge to the true function (dashed black) as the degree increases.
It allows us to replace complicated functions with polynomials
The remainder term gives us explicit error bounds
It reveals how accuracy depends on the step size

children.value: In the next section, we’ll use Taylor’s theorem to derive finite difference approximations for derivatives.
